meanings.definition: To give someone the responsibility of doing something or looking after something.
meanings.sent1: I will entrust you with feeding my pet while I am away.
meanings.sent2: Parents often entrust their children with the task of taking out the trash.
meanings.sent3: I accidentally entrust my keys to the cat instead of my roommate!
meanings.sent4: She decided to entrust her heart to him, hoping he would handle it with care.
meanings.sent5: The teacher had to entrust the class hamster to a student for the weekend.

meanings.definition: To trust someone with something important.
meanings.sent1: Please entrust me with your secret; I promise to keep it safe.
meanings.sent2: It is common for employers to entrust their employees with confidential information.
meanings.sent3: I accidentally entrust my lunch to the office fridge, forgetting to take it home!
meanings.sent4: She chose to entrust her dreams to the wind, hoping they would find a way to come true.
meanings.sent5: The captain had to entrust the ship's wheel to the first mate during the storm.
